prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B9 CO 6-5 line mapping and continuum observation of finger 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is used to identify the distribution of high excitation CO 6-5 emission in the tips of finger 1 of M16. SPIRE spectroscopy indicates the likely continuum level and we can combine the information from 3 spectral windows of the setup (3 + much of the band containing the CO line source) for obtaining continuum information. However -- continuum likely low except for any peaks in the emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Low resolution JCMT observations (11" beam) show 60K lines (White et al 1999, A&A, 342, 233) at a resolution of 0.2km/s for finger 1. This is equivalent to 780Jy -- or ~1200Jy at 0.5km/s resolution. According to our Herschel/SPIRE spectra, CO 6-5 is of order 5 times stronger than CO 4-3, and we assume the same ratio with respect to CO 3-2. Finger 5 has FIR flux is twice that for finger 1 (see Hill et al 2012). So using 0."3 equivalent beam we expect ~10Jy/beam for our ALMA measurements with 0.5km/s resolution. GOAL PROVIDES S/N OF 10 IF 1Jy SENSITIVITY GOAL CHOSEN, assuming CO emission distributed evenly within the original JCMT beam size. Max flux given assumes all JCMT emission is within a single ALMA beam. Bandwidth around CO line allows full coverage of 20-25km/s anomalous velocity features to be mapped (seen by White et al 1999). Possible structures ~6" across -- therefore use ACA. Continuum setup in several base bands -- but will be low S/N (slightly less than 1) unless there are peaks. Therefore 1.2mm asked for in separate science goal.
Bonus lines include CS 14-13, and HC15N 8-7 plus one continuum band which will be of low S/N.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6: mm-wave cold core emission in finger 1 of M16
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observation of the brightest of the fingers of the pillars of creation will look to determine the multiplicity, size and distribution of millimetre cores. This is the setup for 1.2mm continuum observations of finger 1 at 0."3 resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Based on band 6 flux of broad source at tip of finger 2 measured by White et al (1999, A&A, 342, 233). The 0.6Jy continuum source should provide 0.3mJy per ALMA beam (0."3) assuming the emission is uniform within the 13" beam of White et al's original measurements. A goal of 0.064mJy/beam provides a S/N of ~5. Emission is clearly show as breaking up even with the 3-5" resolution of the observations of Fukuda et al (2002, ApJ, 568, L127). Cores of <3" are to be observed so this is the limiting extended source size. No ACA needed.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B9 CO 6-5 line mapping and continuum observation of finger 5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is used to identify the distribution of high excitation CO 6-5 emission in the tips of finger 5 of M16. SPIRE spectroscopy indicates the likely continuum level and we can combine the information from 3 spectral windows of the setup (3 + much of the band containing the CO line source) for obtaining continuum information. However -- continuum likely low except for any peaks in the emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Low resolution JCMT observations (11" beam) show 60K lines (White et al 1999, A&A, 342, 233) at a resolution of 0.2km/s for finger 1. This is equivalent to 780Jy -- or ~1200Jy at 0.5km/s resolution. According to our Herschel/SPIRE spectra, CO 6-5 is of order 5 times stronger than CO 4-3, and we assume the same ratio with respect to CO 3-2. Finger 5 has FIR flux is twice that for finger 1 (see Hill et al 2012). So using 0."3 equivalent beam we expect ~10Jy/beam for our ALMA measurements with 0.5km/s resolution. GOAL PROVIDES S/N OF 10 IF 1Jy SENSITIVITY GOAL CHOSEN, assuming CO emission distributed evenly within the original JCMT beam size. Max flux given assumes all JCMT emission is within a single ALMA beam. Bandwidth around CO line allows full coverage of 20-25km/s anomalous velocity features to be mapped (seen by White et al 1999). Possible structures ~6" across -- therefore use ACA. Continuum setup in several base bands -- but will be low S/N (slightly less than 1) unless there are peaks. Therefore 1.2mm asked for in separate science goal.
Bonus lines include CS 14-13, and HC15N 8-7 plus one continuum band which will be of low S/N.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6: mm-wave cold core emission in finger 5 of M16
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observation of the brightest of the fingers of the pillars of creation will look to determine the multiplicity, size and distribution of millimetre cores. This is the setup for 1.2mm continuum observations of finger 5 at 0."3 resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Based on band 6 flux of broad source at tip of finger 1 measured by White et al (1999, A&A, 342, 233). Scaling by a factor of 2 for the SPIRE observations of finger 5 compared to finger 1 we have a 1.2Jy continuum source. This should provide 0.6mJy per ALMA beam (0."3) assuming the emission is uniform within the 13" beam of White et al's original measurements. A goal of 0.128mJy/beam provides a S/N of ~5. The mm emission is clearly shown as breaking up even with the 3-5" resolution of the observations of Fukuda et al (2002, ApJ, 568, L127). Cores of <3" are to be observed so this is the limiting extended source size. No ACA needed.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: This proposal is to use ALMA and ACA to mosaic two of the pillar tips of the M16 region containing the brightest far infrared sources observed in our Herschel/HOBYS observations. Mosaics in both continuum (1.2mm) and higher excitation spectral lines (notably CO 6-5) will be used to determine the number, masses, mass functions and likely evolutionary state of cores in these induced star forming regions. Our previous low spatial resolution Herschel observations show strong CO spectral lines up to J=13-12 centred on the far-infrared peaks at the tips of the pillars. Molecular line and continuum images with a few arc seconds resolution have shown a handful of cores and molecular line peaks suggesting the existence of a number of pre-stellar and protostellar objects. At the resolution of our ALMA observations we would also expect to be able to observe dynamical structures associated with a number of these cores. In addition, the detailed gas dynamics from the CO line measurements across the pillar tips of the region can help to constrain further our computational hydrodynamic models of pillar formation and evolution under the influence of an advancing ionization front.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00740.S Pillars of creation: exploring their dynamical origins and star-forming fate PI: V. Minier (vminier)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: European Space Astronomy Centre (ESAC), European Space Agency

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Open University, The
Centre for Astrophysics and Planetary Science, Kent, The University of
